subject: EventService : Support async_resolve for subscribers
commitMessage:
EventService : Support async_resolve for subscribers

The http client at bmcweb does not resolve the client's
hostname asynchronously

This commit implements the async_resolve by using systemd resolved.
The async dbus message to resolvd.service is sent when a subscriber
successfully subscribes for events. The method ResolveHostname is
used to resolve the subscriber's hostname

Tested by:
  Subscribe for the events at BMC using DMTF event listener
  Generate an event and see the same is received at the listener's console

Signed-off-by: Sunitha Harish <sunithaharish04@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I3ab8206ac4764cfa025e94c06407524d6ba220e0

Change has been successfully merged by Ed Tanous
These are only used in one place.  Please just inline the definitions.
Done
Doesn't look used?
This is used to send as a dbus method argument in line 137
line 137 is outside the scope of this lambda, so this capture isn't used and can be removed.
Done
This is a vector of IP addresses, which will generate a list of addresses.  You seem to be loading that all into one variable, which is incorrect.
Done
please use the appropriate casing.
Done

This doesn't handle ipv6.

I suspect this whole routine needs simplified to not do the intermediate string conversion.

Address v4 can be constructed from a uint32:
https://www.boost.org/doc/libs/1_66_0/doc/html/boost_asio/reference/ip__address_v4/address_v4.html which can be built from this vector using
if (ipAddress.size() == 4){
    uint32_t address = ipAddress[0] + ipAddress[1] << 8 .....
}

and address v6 can be constructed directly from the vector of bytes:
https://www.boost.org/doc/libs/1_66_0/doc/html/boost_asio/reference/ip__address_v6/address_v6.html

Using these two as an input to the endpoint would avoid the string construction and destruction completely, and have fewer error conditions to handle.
I do not have setup to test for IPv6. So leaving out the ipv6 case with a TODO and debug trace
It's likely 4 extra lines of code that should be pretty tough to do incorrectly.  Please write it, and I will test it for you.
Ack
common error #5

If we're using systemd, we don't need the boost resolver at all, right?  We can just load the IP address directly into a tcp endpoint and call async connect.

something like  https://www.boost.org/doc/libs/1_75_0/doc/html/boost_asio/reference/basic_socket/async_connect.html


In a perfect world, I'd also really like this new resolver type encapsulated in a class that looks a lot like the boost resolver, just to constrain functionality, and make things intermediately testable.

The operator << gives error it its uint32_t

what error?  Did you declare your shifts as unsigned?

something like:
ipAddress[0] << 16U

It also might need to be casted to uint32, but either way, don't use lexical cast here, it's unnecessary.

> Did you declare your shifts as unsigned?
No. 

I get the below error - for which i used int32_t and then casted that to uint32_t which was needed by boost::asio::ip::address_v4 constructor

../http/http_client.hpp:112:53: error: conversion to ‘uint32_t’ {aka ‘unsigned int’} from ‘int’ may change the sign of the result [-Werror=sign-conversion]
  112 |                                   ipAddress[2] << 8 | ipAddress[3];

Please find a way to do this without lexical cast.  I suspect

ipAddress[2] << 8U

Might get you there.

Rather than running through connStateCheck again here, can we just call doConnect directly?  That way, we can just pass endpoint in as an argument, and we won't have to store it in the object for the whole life of the connection.

Nit, callbacks should use boost::beast::error_codes by value.

Do we support multiple endpoints? But don't think, current code is doing that. Its overriding the ipaddress and port during this loop. Ideally this d-bus returns single entry, so do we need to stop when we found valid IPv4 address and return from there by calling doConnect()

> Do we support multiple endpoints? But don't think, current code is doing that. Its overriding the ipaddress and port during this loop. Ideally this d-bus returns single entry, so do we need to stop when we found valid IPv4 address and return from there by calling doConnect()

We need to loop through each entry and add it to the list, then use the overload of async_connect that takes and EndpointSequence.

I dont have a setup which will fetch multiple endpoints. 

As I understood the async_connect overload, it will try connecting to each endpoints. So I suspect this can result in sending same event multiple times to the same subscriber?

> I dont have a setup which will fetch multiple endpoints. 
> 

Please code it correctly anyway.

> As I understood the async_connect overload, it will try connecting to each endpoints. So I suspect this can result in sending same event multiple times to the same subscriber?

No.  It will only connect to a single endpoint.

I mentioned this earlier, but I'd still like to see this functionality wrapped into its own class, with an interface similar to boost::asio::resolver.
That means, there should be a util method which takes the host & port as input and does that method does this async call and returns the resolved endpoint list ?
I would like to see it be a full class, built so its usage is identical to the asio-in tcp resolver.
Done
This does nothing.  We're not using conn in this operation, so setting a timeout has no effect.  Because we're accessing dbus here, we can rely on the dbus timeouts.
Done

please make this look like the asio resolver, which does not take host and port in the constructor.  Instead, it accepts host and service variables in the async_resolve method.

These need not be member variables.
Done
We don't use using namespace in this codebase.  It has the potential to cause namespace collisions.
Done
You need to also return here.  You don't want to continue processing after the handler has been called.

Same as above.  Need to stop executing here.
